title: Kayshon Boutte reflects on his forgotten history as an elite prospect
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Kayshon Boutte was a top high school prospect compared to Stefon Diggs but dropped to a sixth-round NFL Draft pick.
Boutte's sophomore season at LSU was hampered by an ankle injury, affecting his college production and draft stock.
Boutte had a breakout game in Patriots' opener with 103 yards, emerging as a key receiver for quarterback Josh Dobbs.

title: Hasbro is relocating its headquarters to Boston’s Seaport
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Hasbro is relocating its headquarters from Pawtucket, Rhode Island to Boston's Seaport by the end of 2026.
The new headquarters will occupy 265,000 square feet at 400 Summer St. and house about 700 employees.
Massachusetts officials, including Gov. Maura Healey and Mayor Michelle Wu, welcomed Hasbro's move to Boston.

title: Wu heads into preliminary election with massive 50-point lead over Kraft
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Michelle Wu leads Josh Kraft by 50 points in the Boston mayoral race, according to an Emerson College poll.
In Emerson College's recent poll, Wu received 72% support, increasing from a 30-point lead in mid-July.
Boston's preliminary election will narrow candidates ahead of the general election on November 4.

title: Dunkin’ franchisee closes down production plant, lays off 74 employees
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: NGP Management is closing its Haverhill production facility, resulting in the layoff of 74 employees.
The layoffs will affect 45 production workers, 21 drivers, and various supervisors, starting on November 3.
A new Dunkin' manufacturing plant is under construction at 30 Creek Brook Drive, expected to open by year's end.

title: Bill Belichick statue at Gillette? Here’s what more than 1,000 readers said.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: The New England Patriots recently unveiled a 12-foot statue of Tom Brady at Gillette Stadium.
Patriots owner Robert Kraft suggested a possible future statue for coach Bill Belichick, sparking fan debate.
A Boston.com poll showed 46% support for a Belichick statue, while 52% opposed the idea.

title: Pair from Brighton facing charges in string of handicap placard thefts
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Andrea Doucette-Keating, 55, and Zachary Shelton, 37, arrested for handicap placard thefts in the Allston-Brighton area.
Doucette-Keating accused of being the main thief; Shelton allegedly organized the thefts and distributed stolen placards.
Shelton's residence contained stolen placards, tools, and drugs; both face multiple property-related charges in Brighton District Court.

title: Why did the Patriots abandon the run against the Raiders? Mike Vrabel explains.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The Patriots shifted to a pass-heavy strategy, with 46 attempts from Drake Maye, in their loss to the Raiders.
Coach Mike Vrabel cited inefficiencies in the run game and offensive line issues as reasons for abandoning the run.
Rushing attempts were minimal; Patriots' backs combined for 60 yards on 18 carries in the season opener.

title: The T’s ‘fare engagement representatives’ are hitting the streets today. Here’s what to expect.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: MBTA began deploying 'fare engagement representatives' on September 8 to check fares and issue warnings or citations in Boston's subway system.
First offenses for fare evasion result in a written warning, with fines ranging from $50 to $150 for subsequent violations.
Massachusetts decriminalized fare evasion in 2021, but the MBTA addresses revenue loss with stricter fare enforcement policies.

title: Kendrick Bourne reportedly agrees to one-year contract with 49ers
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Kendrick Bourne, 30, signs a one-year contract with the 49ers worth up to $5 million.
Bourne was cut by the Patriots in August, reportedly at his request for more playing time.
Bourne started his NFL career with the 49ers in 2017 as an undrafted free agent from Eastern Washington.

title: The Ocean Club restaurant opens in Martha’s Vineyard landmark bank building
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: The Ocean Club opened August 27 in the historic Martha’s Vineyard National Bank building with chef Marc Orfaly.
The restaurant offers a seafood- and pasta-focused menu and plans to expand its hours beyond current Wednesday-Sunday evenings.
The building retains its original features; a former bank vault serves as a wine cellar and dining area.
